newsitem.title: BELGIUM: FOCUS - CL BELGIUM SAYS FRAUD NO THREAT TO EARNINGS.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - CL BELGIUM SAYS FRAUD NO THREAT TO EARNINGS.

text.p: Credit Lyonnais Belgium (CLB), a unit of French Credit Lyonnais , said on Monday the discovery of a major fraud against the bank earlier this year would have no impact on future earnings.

"The bank had an excellent commercial and financial health in 1996. This trend continued in the first months of 1997 despite the fact the bank was the victim of a large-scale fraud," CLB said in a statement.
"The commercial and financial consequences of that unhappy event are under control so that they will have no impact on future earnings," it added.
The bank said in March a former employee had stolen 3.5 billion Belgian francs in one of the biggest fraud cases in Belgian financial history.
The employee and her husband have since been arrested and three people -- including the head of CLB's internal audit -- have left the bank.

"I am 110 percent sure that every loss relating to the fraud will be fully covered by insurance and through the recovery of the assets that were stolen," CLB chief executive officer Philippe Cloes told a news conference on the bank's 1996 earnings.
The bank's 1996 net profit jumped to 821 million Belgian francs from 628 million a year earlier.
Net profit was 383 million francs in the first quarter of 1997, and Cloes said the bank would earn more than one billion francs net if this year's trend continued.
He said all costs relating to the fraud had been fully provisioned for in 1996, using its fund for internal risks.
He declined to reveal the size of the provisions, but when asked whether they amounted to a few hundred million francs he said "certainly not more than that".
Total 1996 writedowns and provisions stood at 573 million francs, from 651 million in 1995.
Cloes reiterated that his bank is not for sale.

"Credit Lyonnais France has no intention whatsoever of selling CLB...for three reasons: it would not sell a profitable unit; Belgium borders on France and CL France wants to cover its borders; thirdly, we play a key role with a number of specialties in the group, notably in retail (banking), in which we are considered innovative," he said.

The Belgian banking world has seen an exodus of French groups in recent years, the most recent being Paribas Bank Belgium, a unit of French financial group Paribas , sold to Belgian bank Bacob in a deal announced on Friday.
Late last year Belgian Cera Bank agreed to buy Indosuez Bank Belgium from its French parent Banque Indosuez.
In 1994 Banque Nationale de Paris sold Belgian Banque Nagelmackers to a Belgian insurance company.
"The probability of us being sold is very small," Cloes said.
